subject: Re: Problems testing an InputStream
msgSnippet: Hi Chad! ... Eclipse copies your resources to your classpath for you. # it wouldn t be much of an IDE if it didn t, huh? ... Now it s your responsibility.
messageBody:
Hi Chad!


> I am writing a test related to XML parsing. In the setUp() of my test, I read
> an InputStream as follows:
>
> inputStream = this.getClass().getResourceAsStream("sample.xml");
>
> ...where sample.xml is in the same directory as my TestCase.
>
> I then have a "sanity" check test to make sure I read the InputStream correctly:
>
> public void testSampleInputStreamIsValid() {
> assertNotNull("InputStream should not be null", inputStream);
> }
>
> When I run this from within my IDE (Eclipse), it works fine - whether I run the
> test directly, or from a suite (which is in another package).
Eclipse copies your resources to your classpath for you.
# it wouldn't be much of an IDE if it didn't, huh?

> HOWEVER, whenever I run it from Ant or Maven, I get a failure (InputStream is null).
Now it's your responsibility.

Here's a sample ant build.xml extract that I'm using right now:

<target name="compile" description="compile product code">
<mkdir dir="${java.build.dir}" />
<!-- compile the code -->
<javac destdir="${java.build.dir}">
<src path="${java.src.dir}" />
</javac>
<!-- copy the resources -->
<copy todir="${java.build.dir}">
<fileset dir="${java.src.dir}">
<exclude name="**/*.java"/>
</fileset>
</copy>
</target>

for maven, you can associate resources with the <resources> tag:

<unitTest>
<includes>
<include>**/*Test.java</include>
</includes>
<resources>
<resource>
<directory>src/test</directory>
<includes>
<include>**/*.xml</include>
</includes>
</resource>
</resources>
</unitTest>

I think you'll get the picture.


Good luck!

--
